review_title: Listen, value, empower and trust your staff!
pros: - All pros depend on what department you work for. Some people are nice, some people are there to make your life a living hell. - I enjoy not having to worry about interacting with everyone because the higher ups WFH while the peasants need to come to the office 5 days a week. - The pay is higher than other colleges but it’s not as high as other medical colleges. - The wellness program is probably the best benefit. Great incentive to better your health.
cons: - Leadership is awfullllll! I knew a handful of leaders that cared. The other ones need to take effective leadership courses throughout the year. - Onboarding sucked. Very confusing. - Parking is a scam! Depending if you have to be on site, you’re looking to pay $100 per paycheck if you work at the Main Baylor campus. - Administrative offices can be incompetent. Phones did not exist there so don’t even bother calling because you’ll be leaving a voicemail for no reason. They will not get back to you. You’ll be pointed in 20 different directions before you get an answer. - People of color are paid less. - You’ll get a lot of ‘i don’t knows’ and ‘that’s not my job’ - High turnover, a lot of burn out, hierarchy culture and people have either been been at bcm for under 1 year, under 5 years, or 30+ years…there’s no in between. - You also don’t get paid out for vacation time if you resign and on top of that, you have to accrue the time. It is not given to you. They called it modern, they just need to call it what it is…you do not want to pay people when they leave, but you want them to take a year or 2 to get 10 days of vacation out of 365 days in the year. - They streamlined the titles to match titles in a retail store. Directors are now Senior Managers. Associates are now Leads. I thought this was BCM not The Galleria. Education will get you more money than experience. - 7 holidays observed and it does not include the day after Thanksgiving - It was so slow between Christmas and New Year. You could hear a pin drop from the other side of the building…that’s how quiet it was. And if you don’t have vacation time, forget about it. You’re literally wasting money to drive, park, and twiddle your thumbs. The only thing guaranteed at Baylor is the President and his dog’s weekly video.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Houston, TX
pros: -Access to new research techniques/methodology and cutting-edge core facilities. -Access to collaboration across disciplines. -Access to/offers of professional development programs.
cons: -Little-to-no support for postdocs (though this seemed to be variable depending on where you were stationed, especially if you were at a location away from Main Baylor [ie, TCH, Feigin, CNRC, VA, etc.] as well as variable across laboratories). -Management extremely isolated from the reality of the work they expect from laboratory staff/postdocs (ie, Ivory Tower syndrome) -Feigned care for mental health with no actual follow-through (ie, resources offered but unable to attend workshops/therapy sessions due to extremely unreasonable working conditions/hours). At times this also extended to physical health (ie, expectation to ‘work through illness’ especially if work with animals was ongoing; usually due to extreme short staffing and poor planning). -For all of the unreasonable expectations placed on postdoc fellows, the pay was absolutely pathetic. Offering the bare minimum NIH-required salary, with upper-administration mandating that nothing be offered above that, when TMC/Houston is already ranked as one of the least affordable areas/cities for young professionals is insulting as well as a poor management decision.

job_title: Licensed Vocational Nurse (LVN) in Houston, TX
pros: Good benefits, good hours, and good vacation time
cons: The job roles are uncleared. There is no equality between employees. Some people are paid more and do less. They have people working outside of their scope of practice. They have LVN’s triaging, MA’s working as nurses, and management never backing up their employees. They have nurses working and doing management for no pay. They never give raises. The only raises you get are 3% and you have to do a project on top of all of your other responsibilities. There are no separate job roles for people. Clinical staff is working and doing administrative work. They are also the ones answering phone calls, answering messages. This leads to upset patients. There are also providers who have too many patients to handle. The nurses are doing the physicians’ jobs and this leads to more mistakes. The 3 % raise can only happen twice in your career at Baylor and then there is no way to improve.

review_title: Great place to park and do nothing. Terrible place to work and progress.
pros: Relaxed work environment, but not in a necessarily good way. Still, I'll include it as a pro.
cons: The salaries here are way, way below market. They know it and don't care. Incompetence from top to bottom. The relaxed work environment is more about no one caring so it creates an atmosphere of incompetence. You will NEVER get a raise here even after years of working. They profited in the millions during the pandemic and gave no raises. They don't care when a family member dies. They shrug and say sorry and that's all you'll get. And if you take time off for illness or death, they'll give it to you only begrudgingly. Also, there is zero appreciation for any extra effort you provide for the organization. Even if you work hours overtime and go above and beyond, a manager will insist on something that they don't have the technical aptitude to understand that it can't be done and then trash you for not doing it. So why bother? They also don't care about your personal religious holidays. They will schedule meetings on that day. Not an exaggeration. Oh, and the meetings! Meetings after meetings of people talking about what bars are still open during the pandemic and other random stuff while you're wondering when the meeting will be over so you can get back to work on urgent requirements.

review_title: Review of Human Genome Sequencing Center in Baylor College of Medicine
job_title: Senior Bioinformatics Programmer in Houston, TX
pros: Human Genome Sequencing Center is the third largest Genome Sequencing facility. There are many nice problems to solve in Bioinformatics.
cons:
I used to work at Human Genome Sequencing Center as a software engineer at BCM. In my work history of 6 years and 3 companies, I have not seen a more mis-managed organization than this.

Some of the highlights of bad management and brutal wastage of resources
1) Qualified and well-educated engineers, lab-technicians are poorly treated. It does not matter if what an employee says is right or not, he/she must do what the management says.
2) They are trying to solve very large data intensive Computer Science problems and the people who make almost all the decisions such as which hardware to get, how should different components talk to each other have very limited CS knowledge.
3) There were several instances where due to management planning failures, they had less computing resources than required for proper operation. As a result, genome data costing thousands of dollars to generate was lost.
4) They have no concept of Software Engineering design. This is a huge mistake as bad software tools can easily increase the computation time substantially, especially in large data systems like DNA sequencing platforms. For example, a badly developed tool to call SNP on Illumina data was taking days instead of hours.
5) Lack or coordination between different groups generally makes it a lot hard to get anything done. Each group behaved like an autonomous unit instead of working coherently with other 
 
A strong evidence of these drawbacks is that there is continuous exodus of employees from there.

review_title: Not what it used to be
job_title: Senior Administrative Coordinator in Houston, TX
pros: Benefits, leave policies and diversity.
cons:
Administrative staff are not appreciated at Baylor. I spent over a decade there and regret giving them my best years. Most administrative staff are over worked as upper management does not allow departments to open up vacancies as their department's grow. Increasing work loads just keeps getting dumped on the same people. This has been going on for years. Unfortunately the straw that broke the camel's back was when HR decided to "revise" all the administrative titles in 2019. In doing so they moved everyone down 1 to 2 paygrades. They completely eliminated titles in the upper pay grades, leaving no ladder for many of us to climb. Lowering the pay grades meant many would no longer be eligible for a pay raise - EVER - because they had already met the new cap. This was a huge failure and misstep on Baylor's part. They took away incentive for people who had been there for decades to care about reaching new goals and continue in their professional growth. 

Bottom line is if you a physician or medical staff you will probably get paid and treated fairly. If you are administrative staff.... you've been warned. You would do better to go across the street to UT/Methodist/Memorial Hermann/CHI or literally ANY of the other entities in the Texas Medical Center.

job_title: Senior Scientific Programmer in Houston, TX
pros: The best part of the work is contributing to the solution of medical problems and the exploration of basic science that can improve health and the future of humanity.  It is a fantastic place to learn things and participate in creating innovate cutting edge ideas.
cons:
Not having a MD or Phd degree, your promotions and salary increases are very limited.  If you have a PhD your funding is almost always NIH or NSF grants, with award rates around 10-20%.  This can be distracting from research, constantly writing deadend proposals, particularly if the grants are small and you are cobbling them together to keep afloat.  This is not a problem created by BCM, it is a national funding problem of how seriously we value STEM.

If you are a successful PI, you will have a good salary (120k-300k).  Everyone else tends tends to be below (40k-70k) comparable commercial market salaries, figure 10-50% below average.  If you are staff and seek long-term financial promotion, either seek a degree there or move on after a few years.
 
Because they work horse graduate students almost till they drop, the attitude is the same for staff, expecting long hours without additional compensation.  Demand written annual reviews, they tend to blow them off and take you for granted.

pros: Flexible working hours, great exposure to TMC for networking and you are close to a lot of hospitals. Best thing about BCM is the career development office and Derek Haseltine. Great local resources to help you network and prepare for a career after PhD if you can commit the time for them… just a nightmare experience to get the PhD with BCM (Sure this is typically heavily PI dependent, but good luck finding that unicorn here.)
cons: Faculty and admins involve themselves very little in understanding of student’s personal or career development, nor do they innovate much on their program’s community involvement and events. Feels like every PI here started here – all share the same mentality on how research is done and that graduate students are commodities. “Put in your time” and doing as you’re told is all that matters. review_title: It's just not worth it anymore.
job_title: Animal Care Attendant in Houston, TX
pros: The animals, of course, are very cute. You mainly work with mice and rats. There are some opportunities for raises, though not too many. Some staff are friendly and help you find out shortcuts to ease the workload. Benefits, sick days, and vacation days. Some opportunities for overtime on weekends roughly once a month.
cons: You're supposed to work 6 months with mice until you can be considered for working with larger animals, such as sheep, pigs, and primates. What they don't tell you is that it's essentially a promotion, and you might not get the raise until months later. You can get in earlier if you have connections - blatant nepotism. A lot of the researchers that own the animals you take care of look down on you. There are many opportunities to be injured or to put your health at risk. Higher-ups do not seem to care or understand if you are falling behind or if your work performance isn't as good as usual. You are usually not paid positive attention unless you are trying to get your ALAT/LAT/LATG certification. Not really enough pay for the amount of labor you're doing.

job_title: Research Technician III in Houston, TX
pros: The Baylor name definitely has its benefits. There are many things going on here so its nice.  HR is helpful and the staff is well informed. Has its own shuttle. Has amazing cores.
cons: In the middle of the medical center, a block in from the Metro. There are only 3 routes the shuttles take and they don't share with the other buses in the medical center. The college should have a fund that supports the researchers with basic community needs, like autoclaves, ice machines, etc. The departments don't seem to have funds for such things, so the P.I. has to purchase those and share with others.  While the cores are cheaper to us then to outside people, it could be cheaper.

pros:
I think working at a place like BCM is very department-dependent.  The College as a
whole is a good employer.  They offer outstanding benefits and in my experience, offer competitive pay and I've gotten a raise every year.  Any experience in a job is pretty much 100% driven by a person's supervisor.  Mine is awesome, so I feel good about BCM.
cons: Not very many holidays offered, but do give enough time off.  Most of the cons I'd list have to do with my specific department, which is unfair to the College itself.

review_title: Not a bad entry-level job, but leave as soon as you can
job_title: Research Coordinator I in Houston, TX
pros: The hours are flexible and you get to work on interesting research projects. The healthcare is good.
cons:
-Extremely low wages. They intentionally hire individuals who they do not have to pay well (ie, workers on a VISA).  Everything is done to pad their pockets. BCM doesn't seem like they care about their employees. When Harvey came, they skipped our raises that year claiming it was because of the hurricane....even though BCM was unaffected and didn't lose money because of Harvey. They made us donate our vacation time to individuals who needed time off work due to the severe flooding. 

-There is no room for advancement. Your bosses will intentionally give you "average" performance reviews just to avoid giving you a raise. This has happened to me and many other people I know working at BCM. It's a common way to get around giving raises at Baylor.

review_title: BCM is huge, which can be good or bad
pros: Being in the Texas Medical Center is amazing, and BCM collaborates across the board with the hospitals, research organizations, universities, and everything else you can think of. The top-level governance seems to have settled down nicely after the scares in the late 2000s, though that's just from the perspective of a staff member, not a manager.
cons: I felt more like I was at a company than a school; though, to be fair, I was in one of the large research centers rather than in an academic department. It wasn't my center that gave off that feel, but rather the massive BCM organization outside of it -- purchasing, travel, IT.

review_title: Excellent research but very outdated administrative system
pros: BCM provides a wide variety of core lab options to facilitate research, and has successfully navigated into its current position of financial strength and growth from a difficult period several years ago.  The people working at BCM are talented and focused.
cons: BCM has an extremely outdated administrative system for most administrative departments, which can negatively impact the speed of research.  There is also a strong networking system within BCM such that those with excellent contacts are capable of achieving much more than those who are new to BCM or who have yet to develop such contacts.

review_title: " Lack of management skill and productivity"
pros: Great environment to work in, excellent benefits and very understandable manager. Co-worker are willing to help you and facility the initial training process.
cons: Low paid, no annual raise and many of the upper supervisor and team members lack the skills to help and be productive. I felt the the position of many supervisor was earn not because of their skills but because of the amount of years that they had been in the company. There is nothing worse then going to a supervisor with and issue sand getting this in response.." I do not know can you find out and let me know. " the became the number one answer to many if not all of the issues.

review_title: In a campus built and maintained by billionaires, you too can live in absolute poverty
pros: It is a good place to get your H-1B visa.  If  you are a graduate student, great place to spend 8 years.  If you are a post-doc here, forget it, your career is over.  For tenure track faculty, a great place to spend five years until you prove your chops to an ivy league caliber program.
cons: Every single investigator has severe neuroses and psychoses.  You will be made to feel guilty for working 80 + hours for poverty level wages.  At best the lab you will work in is a Potemkin Village to show off for media and investors.  At worst, a giant hamster wheel with no cheese in sight.

review_title: Management Is Stuck in the Past
pros:
Exciting Research
Good people to work with
Good 403b matching plan (which I bet will go away soon given the increasingly frugal nature of management)
cons:
Benefits are terrible. Health insurance is overpriced and network is razor thin. Out of pocket costs are debilitating for lower paid employees.
No paid maternity or paternity leave.
Pay is bad and is not in line with similar positions throughout the country or even within the Texas Medical Center. 
Opportunities for promotion are not met with commensurate increases in pay.
Bad pay and benefits lead to high turnover and general employee dissatisfaction.
Plenty of other options in the med center with better pay, better benefits, and at least the same career opportunities.

pros: Good benefits; accommodating management; good culture
cons: Poor financial situation; survived several rounds of layoffs; stale salaries--no cost of living increases.  My cost of living these days has skyrocketed with gas prices, and my salary has not kept up.  I've had to cut back even though I haven't changed my lifestyle in the past several years working here.  Before the economical downturn Baylor was a 10 out of 10 with great opportunities.  Now it's in a time capsule hoping for things to pick up.  Luckily I got locked in at a decent salary when I started, otherwise I'd really be hurting.  It's still a good place with a good culture though if you can get in.

pros:
Company provides many good benefits, such as tuition assistance, free wellness plan, seminars/CE, 403(b) matching, etc.

Many employees stay for very long periods

Great resource for letters of rec, advancement opportunities, and education
cons:
My position was classified as Research Technician II, but my responsibilities fit a Medical Technologist role almost perfectly (high complexity testing and result reporting directly to pathologist).  My salary was undervalued by about $20K/yr, and I was pushed out when I asked for a salary/position evaluation.

I believe my experience to be in the minority, and had the situation been appropriately handled, I would give a 5 star review.

pros: Well, I was hired by a research assistant professor and not directly by the BCM. Therefore my case could be a little different from others.
cons:
For me, there were too many cons. 
Very small space. we can only put our lunch boxes and drinking bottle immediately out of the lab, and on a small table. There was no a refrigerator and the place was actually in the hall way. 
There also no hot water or a place we can biol water, except the microwave. 
The most important thing is that the specific lab I worked in is not a lab with normal culture, but I believe other labs are much better.

review_title: Your experience will be completely different depending on your department / boss
job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Houston, TX
pros: Baylor is huge, and there is much opportunity to move around, especially if you make a good reputation for yourself.  So many different PIs with different agendas and personalities that you can have a great experience or a terrible one.  When interviewing ask the other folks in the lab how long they've been there, if the PI won't let you talk to anyone else in the lab then be careful there is probably a reason.  There are great labs and PIs and terrible ones, do your homework before joining!  Make sure your PI is well established and well funded, check PubMed to see how many publications they have to help judge longevity and future funding prospects.   If you have a team attitude with the administrative branches of the college (travel, AP, purchasing) they will remember you and be much more helpful and you can get things done with much less fuss than if they dislike you!
cons: If you are administrative then know that some areas pay much better than others and that BCM doesn't seem to think it's a problem to give people wildly different salaries and titles even if they are doing the same job, which is a problem with compensation and HR.  Negotiate a good salary to start because raises are not fabulous.   President Klotman sees administrative functions of the college as "cost lines" not as real contributors, unless he brings them in himself from New York and then they are essential and will have huge pay packets.   Parking is horrendously expensive unless you park in the hinterlands.   The push to get employees to donate portions of their salaries back to the school is insulting, how about cut the huge salaries of the overpaid and multitudinous VPs instead and save tons of cash??

pros: Baylor was really a good job in the beginning, it was easy to get along with people, easy to train, easy work environment, great staff, working with animals for the first time was life changing, the vet staff was a amazing and the pay was good as well.
cons: once new management came in lots of people were moved around to different facilities or they were fired and that made it hard for those of us that were still there because we were short staffed and we had so many animals and it was hard to get the job done. A few people quit because the job became stressful which made the job harder because we had a certain time to have our tasks accomplished and we couldn't stay for overtime.

pros: Work-life balance is very good. You are working in an exciting clinical and research medical environment. The Texas Medical Center is a happening place to work. The people surrounding you are well educated and generally very good at their jobs. There is a lot of collaboration and new technologies being introduced.
cons: The parking is expensive and the commute from most suburbs is long. The organization is less structured so an employees work experience is very dependent on the quality of the immediate supervisor.  If your job is funded through grant money, it must be renewed every 3-5 years and positions can be put at risk based on the funding cycle.

job_title: Linux Systems Engineer in Houston, TX
pros: Very casual environment, great cafeteria with a delicious breakfast menu. Lots of room to grow and learn even for seasoned professionals. Super smart and well educated people. Decent budget, good equipment. Very nice and peaceful outside, serene. Decent salary. Free drinks.
cons: Very low morale, at least with the group I was in, at that time. People stayed in their offices and prefered not to socialize. Had the feeling that everyone hated each other. Problems with open animosity within the group. Ultimately, I didn't feel I was able to connect. For me these problems outweighed all of the benefits.

review_title: This review only apply to postdoc position at BCM
pros: Besides its medical school and hospitals, BCM is also a decent research institute, with good reputation, which will help you if you want have an academic career. You'll know lots of famous scientist, and have lots of collaboration changes. The postdoc payment is fine in south of US. It cannot compete with postdoc position in NY, Boston or CA, but living cost is much cheaper in Houston. So, it balances in some other ways. In addition, they also provide H1B visa for postdoc, since a lot of other institutes will only provide J visa from a foreign country.
cons: They do not provide 401K for postdoc positions, which means a postdoc will take less benefit than a technician.

job_title: Senior Clinical Research Coordinator in Houston, TX
pros: I truly love working for this company. After working for other (not so stellar) hospitals in Houston Baylor is an oasis. Their hiring and onboarding process is easy. The work you do depends on the section/department you end up in, but I found my area to be engaging, fast-paced and fulfilling. The benefits are good, particularly the PTO which rewards you the longer you stay with the company.
cons: Because Baylor has so many affiliates depending on who hires you, you could work at a myriad of other hospitals around the TMC. It hurts the connection you'll have with the main campus, but that is one of the only cons that I can think of.

review_title: A well respected institution in the community in need of a culture change.
job_title: Senior Sponsored Programs Analyst in Houston, TX
pros: Benefits are good. Salary is competitive with other academic institutions in the area. Decent opportunities to grow your career.
cons: Dept resources seem to shrink every year. When you’re  asked to save money via aggressive budget management, those unspent funds are taken away in next years budget. Repeat again next year. Policy changes from some administrative research areas are often not communicated well at all.

job_title: Help Desk Analyst in Houston, TX
pros: I was lucky to work with others on the help desk who were more knowledgeable than I, and they assisted me when an issue arose that I couldn't solve myself.  The managers trusted us to work unsupervised for the most part, and it was nice not having someone breathe down your neck all day.
cons: It is difficult to advance to a better position in the IT Department at Baylor.  While there are a lot of open positions, they seek senior level workers with a lot of experience.  There are few opportunities to be promoted and trained.

review_title: If you're not an MD, forget it!
pros: My colleagues were the best! BCM has minimum turn-over in staff positions. I worked for a 3 year period then left for over ten years. When I returned, many of the same people were still there.
cons: Unfortunately the folks in education don't communicate with the folks in IT and the folks in IT don't communicate with the folks in the college admin offices. Lack of communication is a huge issue.

pros: A chill place with a lot of smart people
cons: Too much bureaucracy. Upper management tends to have a mindset to create stringent and complicated rules that will exempt them from any responsibilities. If something went wrong, they could always claim it was others who broke the rules. But there are way too many rules and regulations that do not make any sense, and so very few are followed, but they create extra work. Such a waste of time!

pros: Great benefits. Great people on the non management level. Medical and graduate students are grounded and mostly good people. Award winning Wellness Program (not to be confused with wellness center).
cons: Management in certain departments is terrible. Unprofessional at best. No advancement. No true leadership to right the ship. No one to look out for employees. Management would rather do what they want rather than what is best for department/business and employees. Often makes employees scapegoat for the incompetencies of management. Terrible communication by management.  Managers don't know what they are doing.

pros: have a good research environment and high quality scientific research facilities in Baylor college of medicine. and also people here are very nice. I can get much help.
cons: Baylor stereotypes do hold some truth. Most of the students seem to white, rich, and conservative so Baylor is lacking in diversity. There are pockets of minority students but if you're liberal, not straight or not Christian you will have a harder time finding friends.

review_title: Positive with research, negative with beaurocracy
pros: Reseach, ability to help people with medical needs.  Ability to further scientific advances for science and health care.
cons: Lack of management capability, structure, strategic goals.  There are a lot of inconsistencies in management, lack of follow through, poor financial management, but they are sure willing to pick up a pay check despite performance issues.  Sort of socialistic in nature with the resultant productivity outcomes.

pros: The benefits are OK and the local work atmosphere is very casual and relaxed because of the people. The location is great for networking and being at the center of research and clinical development is something that institutions outside of the Medical Center lack. At least on paper, it seems that the partnership with Catholic Health Initiatives has increased job security for most Faculty and Staff... However, take that with a grain of salt.
cons:
Perhaps the biggest con is that the administration and upper-management frankly does not care about staff. It's wonderful if you are faculty but be prepared to be thrown under the bus if you are employed as a staff member. BCM states that it "...remains committed to their (employees) dedication and pledge to recognize individual uniqueness and engage all constituencies in guiding our path to excellence in all missions." BCM also states that it is "...dedicated to recruiting outstanding faculty, staff, and trainees..." These statements are nothing more than lip-service and their actions towards staff speak for themselves. 

BCM offers meaningless table scraps in terms of wages for staff positions. For example, a Medical Genetics Technologist I salary is UP TO $40,000. Be prepared to accept a figure as much as $7,500 dollars lower if you apply at BCM. The average salary for a Medical Genetics Technologist according to the Department of Academic Affairs at MD Anderson Cancer center is $42,000 to $46,000. A recent job posting listed an annual salary of $30,000 for a clinical laboratory position, which requires undergraduate degree, but the Houston, TX median annual salary is listed as $63,041 by a reputable salary website. The bottom 10% is $53,638. The data speaks for itself. BCM does not offer competitive wages.

Also, do not expect any salary increases during your employment at BCM. Departmental mismanagement is rife and departmental deficits seem to be the norm. The normal course of action in the mind of a BCM administrator is to punish the employees who actually perform the work that brings in the revenue. Perhaps this is the normal course of action at any institution; however, there is a greater chance that those other institutions actually offer a competitive salary to begin with. Be prepared to be scrutinized for every minute and every penny because we all know that it is the staff making the big bucks. 

Do not expect any potential for growth in your career. The administration is perfectly content with adding responsibilities and duties to your job without actually promoting you. It's also not uncommon to be setup for failure in the institution. The administration will eventually place so many demands and responsibilities that were not yours when you were hired. When you're unable to complete all of those duties, you will be terminated.

review_title: It all depends on the primary investigator, talk with the current staff and postdocs beforehand.
pros: Good funding opportunities allows for continuing research.
cons: Poor management decisions have left BCM financially crippled. Administrative staff layoffs, rolling brownouts of lights and air conditioning, increases to indirect costs, and reduction of employee benefits have all negatively affected morale of faculty, staff and students. Major research faculty are leaving the university which has a negative impact on collaborative efforts. There is no departmental or institutional oversight of postdoctoral fellows and many report negative mentoring experiences.

review_title: Great place to work in the basic biological research and basic research related to human health.
pros: World class facilities. Cores for genomics (aside from the human genome sequencing centre), proteomics, mouse phenotypic analysis. A slew of researchers that work on diverse research areas from modeling to basic research and clinicians
cons: Due to its location and mandate, strictly focuses on biological research

review_title: Outstanding environment for biomedical research and faculty development
pros: Strong research environment.  Highly collegial and collaborative atmosphere.  Excellent research facilities.  Low cost of living in Houston.  Strong support for diversity in student body, faculty, and staff.
cons: Lack of hard money for faculty salaries.  Recent cutbacks due to financial crisis. Challenging to recruit best students and faculty to Houston if they come from east or west coast.

review_title: Many good people, low pay, no talent retention
pros: My coworkers were wonderful and talented people. There always seems to be free food around. Great benefits and retirement plan.
cons: Leadership is completely clueless and apathetic about the struggles of daily work. Workloads are unrealistically heavy, and hiring new people takes forever. Salaries are not based on performance and are not even discussed during the same time of year. Leadership will not even negotiate retaining talented people. The commute/parking situation is terrible and expensive.

pros: If you get a good advisor you will get interesting work.
cons: Postdocs here are paid the minimum allowed by the NIH. BCM won't allow advisors to pay more. Ridiculous. This place loves silly rules too. I have to turn in time sheets even though I'm salaried and no one seems to know what the time sheets are for. When you travel for work you have to save all your restaurant receipts which is a giant waste of time and effort. When I travelled for another university they just did a per diem, no receipts. Much better.

pros: BCM is a prestigious university and is part of the largest medical center in the world, meaning the resources available are endless.
cons: There is some elitism on the part of the institution when it comes to faculty and especially the clinicians.  As faculty, we do get some perks but I don't think it's quite fair when someone with the same degree and experience as a faculty member gets less vacation time, etc. because they are staff.

job_title: Animal Care Attendant in Houston, TX
pros:
Benefits are great! 
If you do your job and show management that you are responsible and RELIABLE you can move up rather easy! 
Very team orientated.
cons:
Paying to park and riding the shuttle, which can make you late at times! 
People who don't pull their own weight make everyone who performs well suffer.

pros: Opportunity to contribute to meaningful research. Happened to have a great boss who was pretty hands off. Got to work on a variety of projects, from clinical to database. Worked with collaborators closely at the VA, Ben Taub hospital and a community clinic.
cons: The pay was pretty terrible. With a graduate degree in public health from a nationally ranked school I was only making $40,000 per year. I took the job for the reputation of the institution.

job_title: Human Resources Analyst in Houston, TX
pros: People in almost every department were very nice.  I would work there again happily.  Benefits package is very good.  I was able to work a flexible schedule which helped my work/life balance quite a bit.  I had a great manager!
cons: A little bit bureaucratic, getting a process changed is laborious.  Pay is a little low, but work/life balance made up for that.

review_title: Good opportunity, flexible work environment, but low salary.
pros:
* Good chance to write a paper
* Collaboration with biology/medical field
* Diverse and friendly co-workers
* Flexible work hour / working from home
* Benefits: Good insurances (even for your pet), greate-value 401(a), the company equally contributes 401(b) with what you contribute and occasional fun events
cons:
* Collaboration with biology/medical field
* Low salary
* Too many projects you have to handle at once

pros: Some flexibility and nice staff to work with...
cons:
Horrible pay.  In the 3 years I worked with them, my salary went up 2%!  Pay for parking!  Expect alot for the pay and no job satisfaction.  When I wanted to switch my job role, they wouldn't allow me.  Job experience isn't good enough for me to find a job when I want to shift to a different job role.  
 
Baylor is known for their education, not for their employees!

review_title: Don't look to get above the poverty line
pros: Health insurance was great,  but very expensive, especially if you have dependents.  Coffee shop and Luby's cafeteria on site. Nothing else good about this place
cons: Never got a raise in 6 years.  Not even cost of living.  No parking.  HR is on another side of the medical center so good luck with that.

review_title: Great place to gain experience but not really to build a career
pros:
Ability to work with great minds, great science
Great 403b matching
Great place to work if you just need to exist
Low cost of living @ Houston TX
Won't ever need a snow jacket or boots
cons:
No particular career path
Mostly chaotic
You always have politics at work but here there's a LOT of politics!

pros: The benefits at BCM are great. You can take  great care of yourself and family these are the best benefits you can get.  Most positions are also flexible/family friendly. They understand if you have to leave early or come in late for personal reasons.
cons: No real growth. You have to leave positions in order to grow. A lot of people will hire friends and choose who they want to grow.  You could do a great job and still have to fight for growth.

review_title: Baylor college of medicine is a good place to work and learn.
pros:
Students and post docs are nice. 
Boss is okay 
Equipments are new and the service teams are always helpful.
Shuttle is free
cons:
Micro manipulation 
No raise at all. They would rather use their money to do more experiments than pay you a penny.
Lazy people do not get punished and hard-working people do not get respected and rewarded

No promotion at all.

Parking is extremely expensive.

review_title: Depends on your department, research beforehand.
job_title: Senior Project Coordinator in Houston, TX
pros: Professional recognition in being associated with the University and the benefits.  I think satisfaction there is highly dependent upon which department you work for.
cons: Incompetent leadership and not willing to change old processes in order to ensure continued growth and efficiency within departments.  Raises are rare and low.  Depending on your title, they don't pay on a scale consistent with other companies.

job_title: Senior Bioinformatics Analyst in Houston, TX
pros: I works for a group which has cutting edge data and it works out for me. I think its a good place to get a lot of publications and learn. Although I cannot see myself being there for more than 3-4 years. People are OK. And since they haven't worked in any other place except Baylor they are not so professional.
cons:
People are not so great.
No order or professionalism.
Too much monopoly of a certain person and too much politics
HR sucks!

review_title: PostDoc at Baylor College of Medicine, a good decision
pros:
Based in the largest medical center in the world, so there are additional opportunities for networking

Very collaborative, all P.I.s generally seem to want to help each other

Work hours are reasonable and benefits are quite good
cons:
Private university, so maintaining lab funding is somewhat more difficult than at a state or government funded university, since all lab personnel are supported from grants with no additional support from the university

No undergraduate component, so if you want to teach there are very few opportunities

review_title: My experience at BCM has been awesome, considering I work for one of the most trifling and non-people friendly boss.
pros: The good thing about working for BCM is that you get a wonderful chance to build experience.
cons: The hard part about working for BCM is that everything you request or have an issue with takes forever to get taken care of....no sense of urgency.

pros: It is nicely integrated with the world's largest medical center (Texas medical center).  It is easy to get things done, with extensive expertise in different field of science.  Houston offers excellent weather except in the summer.
cons: Baylor administration is on big financial crunch, they build a big hospital but unable to complete it due lack of funding.  Since the past administration had put lot of money on this, the hiring phase in Baylor is reduced significantly.

job_title: Front Desk Specialist II in Houston, TX
pros: The clients and customers made it a great place to provide service.
cons: The hours working was long sometime from 8am-8pm know quality time to spend with your family.  When I left I was completely burnt out. The common phase used was overworked and underpaid.

review_title: I have learned and grown my research experience there for 9 years.
job_title: Research Coordinator I in Houston, TX
pros: The best medical benefit package in all of Texas Medical Center.  Seniority is always good and there is room to grow.
cons: Currently they have been on an annual raise freeze for this year and in the past in 2007 it was for two years in a row due to BCM failed investments.

pros: Baylor College of Medicine offers a number of positive programs for employees including a generous 3 year vesting 401A employer funded retirement program, Vitality Program for promoting health.
cons: Organization is at cross-roads with challenging issues with its key clinical relationship with CHI which impacts the organization's finances. Also changes in federal funding for research places additional strain. Organization lacks a primary care network which is adversely impacting clinical practices.

review_title: Not a healthy environment for graduate students
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Houston, TX
pros:
Top research institution- looks good on a resume or CV.
Depending on the research program, BCM has state-of-the-art facilities and core laboratories.
cons:
Graduate students are extremely underpaid and exploited for their work.
Many students and research technicians are mistreated or exploited by their boss (usually a principal investigator).

pros: A wonderful learning experience. The researchers were very helpful in training me in the lab and including me in their work.
cons: A specific project was not assigned to me. I assisted different group members in the lab with their work, so at the end of the internship I did not have one cohesive project to show for my work. However, this was expected for an internship. Nevertheless, being able to learn different techniques with different lab technicians was very valuable.

review_title: Real disconnect and lack of appreciation from senior, or "important" faculty.
job_title: Research Technician II in Houston, TX
pros: There is great motive to work hard in the great clinical research. Baylor overall has a very friendly and welcoming demeanor, however the individual PI's are a different story.
cons: There is never any appreciation for work being done by clinical lab faculty. They run lab techs like machines to produce their product. No investment in young scientists, only the necessity for willing and capable hard workers.

pros: Great benefits. Training opportunities, opportunity to grow and promote from within
cons: I enjoyed my time at Baylor but often felt penalized off having a family. When my family obligations kept me from working late nights or long weekends, I was often told that I was not carrying my weight on projects. Did not feel support from upper management on work, life balance.

pros: Part of the largest medical center in the world with world-renowned leaders in every field of Medicine. Incredible experience that has shaped the future of my career in one short year.
cons: If you are looking for an easier, more laid-back atmosphere, this is not the work environment for you. The volume is so great that the simplest jobs become more challenging than they may ordinarily be. The work is rewarding if you are willing to do the job.

pros: Nice facilities and world class researchers combine to make this a great place to learn. Located at the Texas Medical Center, which includes many of the best medical centers in the US.
cons: Parking at the Texas Medical Center is very expensive and Houston public transportation isn't great. I rode my bike to work and was jarred awake every morning with a near death experience with a "texas cadillac".

job_title: Animal Lab Tech in Houston, TX
pros: Great benefits, oppuntunity to grow. Friendly surrounding gym right in the medical center. Love the different food cafeteria you can choose from
cons: The particular department I worked in was a little over the top.. Drama drama drama. If you stick to your self you will be fine.

review_title: I work in the administrative side.
pros: Best medical benefits and paid time-off; employee perks and discounts are cool; job security; get to learn first hand about the latest break-throughs in science and medicine.
cons: Commuting to the medical center; lots of top-level politics; poor interdepartmental communication; lack of on the job training; poor budgeting; not enough people to handle expanding job responsibilities. Parking actually gets taken out of your paycheck.

review_title: Nice environment but raises are hard to come by.
job_title: Systems Engineer II in Houston, TX
pros: Environment is very laid back and easy to get along with everyone.  Benefits are very good as well.  Health care is affordable and the 401 package is not so bad either.
cons: Raises - they just don't exist.  That is really the only problem I have had since working here for almost 4 years.(Only one raise)

pros: Great place to collaborate with many different labs at BCM and surrounding institutions. Equipment is state-of the art. BCM is well integrated in the Texas Medical Center. Faculty members are very well trained scientifically. Great mentors.
cons: Poor financial and people management. Poor career advice and assistance to students and postdocs. No retirement benefits for postdocs.

pros: Great place to work.  Exciting research.  Rapidly changing environment. Brilliant colleagues and staff.  International leader in human genetics research.
cons: Pay is low, turnover is high, giving great opportunity for advancement.  Staff level lab work can be repetitive.  Lots of opportunities for programmers.

review_title: If there is funding and decent performance, a postdoc can stay forever as postdoc because the PI don't want competitors
pros: Nice facilities, some interesting science, smart people in the neighborhood, low cost of living in Houston
cons: Cut throat competition, politics (kiss up to PI), low pay (below NIH standard), no pay raise, no mentoring, no career development, long hours, no work-life balance, no career advancement, sometimes wasting tax payers money on frivolous things, no benefits, time off policy is a joke

job_title: Research Assistant II in Houston, TX
pros: I gained experience in the field.
cons: Before starting the job, I was required to train and do it on a "volunteer" basis for two months while waiting for management to finalize my employment. I was paid full time but less than a living wage with a bachelor's degree in STEM. I was paid hourly but expected to put in hours in addition to my normal work week without compensation. I was expected to work with animals in an extremely loud-background noise environment, and I was prohibited from wearing hearing protection. I suffered hearing loss because of this.

pros: Baylor has a great resources, such as the state-of-the art fMRI machines or exhaustive behavioral labs.  Many of the professors and researchers are open to collaboration or communication with a good reason.
cons: It can be hard to network or branch out of your immediate lab. The work, of course, is grant-based and some of your time will be directed not towards

pros: Working with cutting edge technologies, diverse population of employees, nice Christmas party

review_title: One of the best places to do postdoc

cons: Private school. labs and research are pretty much depend on funding and grants. Sad to see many friends and neighbors leave when run out of funding. As a postdoc usually not get teaching opportunities.

review_title: Great learning experience to broaden my knowledge.  Baylor provides the best of patient care.
job_title: Plastic Surgery Division in Houston, TX

pros: Stable job.  No layoffs in my department.  401k contribution 8% regardless of what employee contributes.   Vacation increases with tenure.

pros: there are good and friendly coworkers. Houston is nice city to live with a lot of fun. World largest medical center provide a good opportunity to learn.
cons: Baylor college of medicine is suffering from financial issues. Humid and hot weather in houston with low cost of living. less professional growth opprotunity.

pros: Staff, Surrounded by professionals, Opportunity and location.

review_title: Great place to work, but be picky about your department

pros: Benefits are decent, not too expensive

review_title: Not a great company to work for

cons: No option to work from home, salary is terrible for all employees except doctors and most research studies are all about the money and getting patients to consent and say yes to studies

pros: the people, the city, the Texas medical center, very diverse culture and leading edge technology and research that you are exposed to.

pros: Esteemed medical school, good benefits for faculty,  great reputation, better paying medical school system in Houston

review_title: Baylor College of Medicine a world leader in Medicine.

too many Indians and not enough cheifs!

review_title: okay place if you have to work at Houston
pros:
1) Relatively big research hub.

cons:

job_title: Animal Care Attendant in Houston, TX
pros:
- Very good health benefits. 
- Consistent, predictable hours. 
- Lots of PTO, it accumulates quickly. 
- The mice and rats are very cute. 
- You will meet some genuinely hard-working people. 
- You have many opportunities to build positive working relationships with other ACAs, since you see the same people every day. 
- No interaction with the general public. 
- Some opportunities for overtime. 
- The facility is kept at a comfortable temperature. 
- No dress code since you wear scrubs that are provided for you.
cons:
- Communication between management, ACA team leads, and ACAs was horrible. Assignments are given with very little notice, which puts you behind on your own work. 
- Very labor intensive, which would be fine if the pay was fair. Your work is expected to be faultless. 
- The social environment between the ACAs is, for the most part, toxic and vicious. Most of your coworkers will constantly be looking for reasons to gossip about you or blame you for anything that goes wrong in the workplace. Harassment is so common and expected that no one will come to your defense, and you will be branded a snitch if you try to defend yourself. 
- It's highly discouraged to ask for help from coworkers due to the above point, even though you'll often need to due to the unfair workload. 
- Morale is incredibly low. The ACAs that have been there longer than 1-2 years are disillusioned and passionless. 
- Nepotism and favoritism runs rampant. Favorites of management are allowed to do things that any other ACAs would get written up for, such as slack off, neglect their animals, and leave their vivariums dirty. 
- Research staff is unfriendly at best and malicious at worst. 
- Research staff is often incompetent, will kill their own animals due to improper procedures, and then blame it on you. Management will side with them. 
- Management will see any disturbance in your work performance as you not caring about your job. They do not care to understand your personal life, mental health, or physical health. They will work you until you drop. 
- Management is discriminatory and regularly violates Title IX policies. 
- Management turns a blind eye to harassment and sexual harassment. 
- The turnover rate for ACAs is very high due to all of the above. Most do not last more than one year. 
- You have a high risk of developing animal allergies. 
- Parking in any of the garages is ridiculously expensive, especially for your low pay.
